conclusion: Analyze forces on the metal rod to determine spring elongation when current I_2 flows.
Metal rod suspended horizontally by two identical springs in a uniform magnetic field pointing into the paper.
Lorentz force acts on a current-carrying conductor in a magnetic field.
Lorentz force per unit length is F = I L B.
Right-hand rule determines Lorentz force direction.
Lorentz force acts upward when current flows from b to a and magnetic field points into the paper.
Springs do not stretch when current I_1 flows, implying Lorentz force balances rod weight.
F_1 = W, where W = mg.
Substitute F_1 = I_1 L B to get I_1 L B = mg.
Relate current I_1 to rod weight using I_1 L B = mg.
Current I_2 flows through the rod, I_2 > I_1.
Lorentz force F_2 = I_2 L B.
Net upward force F_net = F_2 - W.
Substitute F_2 = I_2 L B and W = I_1 L B to get F_net = (I_2 - I_1) L B.
Net upward force causes springs to stretch.
Hooke's law determines spring elongation.
F_net = 2kx, where k is spring constant and x is elongation.
Substitute F_net = (I_2 - I_1) L B to get (I_2 - I_1) L B = 2kx.
Solve for x: x = (I_2 - I_1) L B / 2k.
Final answer: Elongation of springs is x = (I_2 - I_1) L B / 2k.
